unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: One-Sample T-Test Output
question_text: An exercise physiologist is interested in the effect of exercise on heart rate. She has subjects walk slowly for $5\text{ minutes}$ and records their heart rates. Then she has the subjects run vigorously for $5\text{ minutes}$ and records their heart rates again. The differences are recorded, (heart rate after running - heart rate before running), with results below: One-Sample T: Differences Test of $\mu$ = $0$ vs. > $0$ Variable N Mean StDev SE Mean 96% CI T P Differences 12 59.88 10.36 3.66 (51.22, 68.53) 16.35 0.000 What is a valid interpretation of the hypothesis test given from the computer output?

choices.text: Strong evidence exists that heart rate increased by about 60 beats 60 beats (after - before running).
Strong evidence exists of an increase in heart rate (after - before running).
There was a failure to find strong evidence of an increase in heart rate since the sample is so small.
There was a failure to find strong evidence of an increase in heart rate because this sample clearly contains bias.
There was a failure to find strong evidence of an increase in heart rate because of the low p p -value.
